docs.abstract: Facebook’s earnings report sent tech stocks cratering. But don’t let that fool you: Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are still on their way to dominating the future.
docs.snippet: Facebook’s earnings report sent tech stocks cratering. But don’t let that fool you: Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are still on their way to dominating the future.
docs.lead_paragraph: You may have heard that the tech giants are on their heels.

headline.main: Stumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as Ever
headline.print_headline: Why Big Tech, Even Now, Is as Big as Ever

docs.abstract: Being hooked on devices is as likely a symptom of stress and anxiety as a cause.
docs.snippet: Being hooked on devices is as likely a symptom of stress and anxiety as a cause.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple has introduced new software designed to help users restrict the time they spend on their phones — just change your settings and your favorite app will lock you out after a certain number of hours. It’s been especially welcomed by parents who fret about the habits of their “screenagers” — young people who seem permanently attached to their mobile devices.

headline.main: Taking Away the Phones Won’t Solve Our Teenagers’ Problems
headline.print_headline: Teens Are Stressed. But Don’t Just Blame Phones.

docs.abstract: Accused of using its App Store to undercut competitors, Apple said Spotify was treated like all other developers that use the App Store.
docs.snippet: Accused of using its App Store to undercut competitors, Apple said Spotify was treated like all other developers that use the App Store.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Apple responded on Friday to antitrust claims made by the music streaming service Spotify, saying its policies are fair and accusing its rival of being motivated by a need to bolster financial results.

headline.main: Apple Defends App Store Policies After Spotify’s Antitrust Complaint
headline.print_headline: Apple Defends App Store Policies After Spotify’s Complaint

docs.abstract: Digital assistants from Amazon, Apple and Google can only have meager back-and-forth exchanges with us. Listen to how that tells us something about where they’re going in the future.
docs.snippet: Digital assistants from Amazon, Apple and Google can only have meager back-and-forth exchanges with us. Listen to how that tells us something about where they’re going in the future.
docs.lead_paragraph: Digital assistants from Amazon, Apple and Google can only have meager back-and-forth exchanges with us. Listen to how that tells us something about where they’re going in the future.

headline.main: Alexa vs. Siri vs. Google: Which Can Carry on a Conversation Best?

byline.original: By Keith Collins and Cade Metz

docs.abstract: The article by Nathaniel Rich, published in The New York Times Magazine this month, detailed how a group of scientists, activists and politicians tried to stop climate change.
docs.snippet: The article by Nathaniel Rich, published in The New York Times Magazine this month, detailed how a group of scientists, activists and politicians tried to stop climate change.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A recent New York Times Magazine article about climate change and the political forces that have stymied efforts to combat the phenomenon will become an Apple television project.

headline.main: Apple Buys Rights to Series Based on New York Times Climate Change Article
headline.print_headline: Apple Buys TV Rights To Article On Climate

docs.abstract: Timothy D. Cook of Apple, Ginni Rometty of IBM and dozens of other C.E.O.s said new guidelines and practices were hindering skilled foreign workers and harmful to economic growth.
docs.snippet: Timothy D. Cook of Apple, Ginni Rometty of IBM and dozens of other C.E.O.s said new guidelines and practices were hindering skilled foreign workers and harmful to economic growth.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dozens of American business leaders are challenging the Trump administration over changes to immigration policy that they say threaten the livelihoods of thousands of their skilled foreign workers, and the nation’s economic growth and competitiveness as well.

headline.main: Top C.E.O.s Denounce Trump Immigration Policy as Threat to U.S. Economy
headline.print_headline: Business Leaders View Immigration Policy as Threat to Economy

docs.abstract: The European Union, which has emerged as the world’s toughest overseer of technology, said the deal did not pose any threat to competition.
docs.snippet: The European Union, which has emerged as the world’s toughest overseer of technology, said the deal did not pose any threat to competition.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — European authorities on Thursday cleared Apple’s acquisition of the popular song-recognition app Shazam, after months of study into whether the deal would give the iPhone maker an unfair advantage over rival streaming music services like Spotify.

headline.main: Apple’s Takeover of Shazam Is Cleared by European Regulators
headline.print_headline: Apple Takeover of Shazam Clears Europe’s Regulators

docs.abstract: With Apple expected to introduce pricier and bigger-screen iPhones this week, here are a few tips on how to upgrade your device without breaking the bank.
docs.snippet: With Apple expected to introduce pricier and bigger-screen iPhones this week, here are a few tips on how to upgrade your device without breaking the bank.
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s the time of year when smartphone makers introduce their newest wares to tempt you to spend your hard-earned dollars on the latest, priciest devices.

headline.main: New iPhones Are Coming. Here’s How to Save on an Upgrade.
headline.print_headline: Upgrading to a New Smartphone? Here’s How to Save

docs.abstract: The threat stops short of compelling tech companies to give access to intelligence officials from Australia, Britain, Canada, New Zealand and the United States.
docs.snippet: The threat stops short of compelling tech companies to give access to intelligence officials from Australia, Britain, Canada, New Zealand and the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration and its closest intelligence partners have quietly warned technology firms that they will demand “lawful access” to all encrypted emails, text messages and voice communications, threatening to compel compliance if the private companies refuse to voluntarily provide the information to the governments.

headline.main: ‘Five Eyes’ Nations Quietly Demand Government Access to Encrypted Data
headline.print_headline: Five Intelligence Partners Quietly Demand Access To Encrypted Technology

byline.original: By David E. Sanger and Sheera Frenkel

docs.abstract: Companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index bought back a record $189.1 billion of their shares during the second quarter, up nearly 60 percent from a year ago.
docs.snippet: Companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index bought back a record $189.1 billion of their shares during the second quarter, up nearly 60 percent from a year ago.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: Buybacks Continued to Boom Last Quarter: DealBook’s Closing Bell
